page.title: 02HISTORY OF TEIGNMOUTH
page.content: The history of Teignmouth has a lot to do with the sea. Saxons and Celts fought a battle on the Ness which sticks out like a nose or "Nez". Danes sailed up river and burnt huts down. The French came twice. In 1690 they destroyed the town. There are stories about Press Gangs and a priest's hole at the Jolly Sailor Inn and a smugglers' tunnel at Holcombe. Jobs were things like saltworking and shipbuilding-some for Henry VIII. Fishermen went all the way to Newfoundland while their wives fished at home. Next, holidaymakers came to bathe and smell the sea air. Beautiful buildings e.g. Den Crescent and Bitton House were made for the rich visitors. In the Second World War German planes tried to flatten Teignmouth-the most bombed in the Southwest, for its size anyway.
